frameDefinitions: An Entity undergoes some change (the Event) that is (or is construed as) punctual.
An Agent occupies a Role in some institution.
A Performer has a certain Role in a Performance and plays their part by following the directions in the Script for that particular Role.
This frame is  concerned with the percepts that vibrations which travel through the air or another medium produce in hearing organs.
An Event with multiple Participants takes place.
The words in this frame involve an Undesirable_event which affects the Patient negatively.
frameExamples: This <t>happens</t> to me all the time.
Chris <t>served</t> as chairman of the boardfor one year.
Margaret Thatcher <t>played</t> Juliet in a school play.
I awoke to the <t>clash</t> of a jackhammer on concrete.
MATAC looks forward to your <t>participation</t> in helping promote telework in the Mid-Atlantic region.
The first <t>calamity</t> was a disastrous trade war with Holland.
listRoleDefinitions: This role identifies the event which occurs and affects the <fen>Entity</fen>.
This role identifies the entity, concrete or abstract.
This role identifies the time when the event occurs.
This role identifies where the event takes place.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the entity that occpuies the <fen>Role</fen>.
The <fen>Role</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> occupies.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> served in the <fen>Role</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> served in the <fen>Role</fen>.
The <fen>Audience</fen> experiences the <fen>Performance</fen>.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Performer</fen> to transmit the <fen>Performance</fen> to the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The <fen>Performer</fen>s generates the <fen>Performance</fen> which  the <fen>Audience</fen> perceives.
The <fen>Performer</fen> provides an experience for the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The music which may be performed in the <fen>Performance</fen>, either in isolation or accompanying actions and speech.

The (usually written) directions which instruct the <fen>Performer</fen>s on what actions to perform, when, and how.  It has many different names depending on the <fen>Type</fen> of <fen>Performance</fen> including <ment>script</ment>, <ment>screenplay</ment>, <ment>libretto</ment>, <ment>book</ment>, and <ment>choreography</ment>.
This role indicates the subtype of <fen>Performance</fen>, including <ment>dance</ment>, <ment>theater</ment>, <ment>film</ment>, etc.

<fen>Role</fen> identifies one of the possible relations that the <fen>Performer</fen> can have to the <fen>Performance</fen>.  The <fen>Role</fen> (s) a <fen>Performer</fen> has in the <fen>Performance</fen> will determine which parts of the <fen>Script</fen> should be performed by the <fen>Performer</fen>, as the <fen>Script</fen> is written in terms of which <fen>Role</fen> (s) each set of instructions applies to.  In the fields of theater, movies, ballet, and opera, a <fen>Role</fen> generally corresponds to a character in the story of the <fen>Script</fen>, while other types of performance may use more general <fen>Role</fen>s like <ment>lead violinist</ment>.
The person that performs alongside Performer2.
The person that is also in the Performance, alongside Performer1.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when an event occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> an event occurs.
An entity that is construed as a single point source emitting sound.

The location at which sound is produced. This role differs from Location_of_sound_source in that it does not highlight the sound's spreading from its source to the perceiver's location, which is usually indicated by the preposition 'from'.
The individuals or entities that have been participants in an <fen>Event</fen>.
<fen>Participant_1</fen> is the grammatically more prominent participant in an <fen>Event</fen> with multiple <fen>Participants</fen>.
A grammatically less prominent participant of an <fen>Event</fen> with multiple <fen>Participants</fen>.
An <fen>Event</fen> with multiple <fen>Participants</fen>, who may or may not be involved intentionally.
A group, location, or institution conventionally associated with an <fen>Event</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the multiple-participant <fen>Event</fen> occurs.
The location where the <fen>Event</fen> involving multiple <fen>Participants</fen> occurs.
The undesirable event which occurs.
The entity that experiences the <fen>Undesirable_Event</fen>.
When the <fen>Undesirable_Event</fen> occurs.
Where the <fen>Undesirable_Event</fen> takes place.
listRoleExamples: He co-starred <fex>with Matt Perry</fex> in Tool 3.
Who co-starred <fex>with Glen Close</fex> in that space opera thingy?
He woke up because of the blare <fex>of a car horn</fex>.
There was a clatter of running feet <fex>in the street outside</fex>.
Thereafter, <fex>everybody</fex> participated in the 17 May parade ending in the Nordic Club.
Last year, <fex>Bill</fex> participated in the Montana State University Earth Systems Science distance learning course in the Atmosphere Unit.

The Second Amended Complaint alleges that Andrew S. Pitt ('Pitt'), Conectisys Corporation ('Conectisys' or the 'Company'), and BM
Capital Corp. participated <fex>with Zaman and Smith Benton</fex> in a fraudulent and manipulative trading scheme.
Some who participated <fex>in D-Day</fex> are finally ready to talk about it
Several of the countries were unable to participate <fex>in the market</fex> .

A survey of students who participated <fex>last year</fex> showed that 61 percent would be the
first in their family to attend college.
The most exciting tours for Mr. Osako were when he participated <fex>in France, Belgium, Holland, Cuba and Japan</fex>.
An <fex>environmental</fex> disaster is just what we need.

passageCandidateSpans.text: Lost Years: A People's Struggle for Justice

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Chinese Head Tax and Exclusion
